_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Basic Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Kemira Water Solutions, Inc. (Kemira) operates in a facility located at 3761 Canal Street, East Chicago, Indiana.  This facility manufactures ferric chloride (FeCl3), ferrous chloride (FeCl2) and other chemicals for the water treatment industry using chlorine gas as one of the raw materials.  Chlorine has been identified by the Environmental Protection Agency as a regulated substance subject to section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act (CAA), which requires the preparation of this Risk Management Plan (RMP).  Chlorine is the only chemical on the EPA list present at the Kemira facility in an amount and concentration exceeding the applicability threshold.  In addition, due to the presence of chlorine, Kemira is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management standard and is submitting a program level 3 Risk Management Plan.

Chlorine is a listed toxic substance under the Risk Management Plan regulations found at 40 CFR 68 and is subject to those regulations since it is stored in quantities in excess of 2,500 pounds.

Kemira utilizes chlorine as a raw material to produce FeCl3.  Kemira receives railcars with chlorine, Spent Pickle Liquor (SPL), and Hydrochloric Acid (HCl) at their East Chicago facility.  Chlorine gas is received in 90-ton (180,000 lb) rail tank cars.  Normally, six (6) rail tank cars at a time are present onsite, but occasionally up to 20 rail tank cars could be present.  Only one rail car is connected to the process at any one time.  The maximum amount of chlorine that can be stored at this facility is 3,600,000 pounds.  This substance is stored in rail tank cars under ambient temperature conditions, which could exceed 100 degrees F in the summertime.  Normal internal pressure is 60 to 70 psi, but on a hot day pressures may reach 180 psi in the process.

Chlorine gas is piped from the railcars to the reaction vessels (chlorinators), where it reacts with ferrous chloride to form ferric chloride.  There are three reaction vessels.  Each reaction vessel is fitte

d with two, independent, pressure safety devices.  In case of a reaction vessel over pressurization, spring-loaded pressure relief valves would discharge the chlorine into a process tank of ferric chloride.  In the unlikely event of a continued over pressurization, a rupture disk is utilized as an additional safety feature and the chlorine is captured.  Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.

All design has been based on what will result in the safest and most environmentally sound operation.  The process is a proprietary closed system.  The portion of scrap iron and carbon not digested ends up in a filter press, which is shipped offsite to a landfill.

RMP regulations require offsite consequence analysis for a potential release of chlorine to the atmosphere.  Kemira is required to consider two release scenarios, identified as a worst case and an alternative scenario.  The worst case scenario is defined by the EPA, which states that the owner or operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released as a gas over a 10 minute period due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative scenario is defined as more likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario.  To determine the area of impact, Kemira used an air dispersion modeling program named RMP*COMP which is recommended by the EPA.

Worst -case release scenario
The Clean Air Act risk management planning regulations require Kemira to prepare a worst-case scenario consisting of the release of the entire contents of the largest vessel containing a regulated chemical in 10 minutes.  The largest chlorine-containing vessel is a rail car, whose content totals 90 tons (or 180,000 pounds).  Therefore, the rate of release would be 9 tons/minute (18,000 pounds/minute).  RMP*Comp (version 1.07), assists in estimating the distance to a toxic endpoint in the event of a release as described above.  The U.S. EPAA?s

all applicable state codes and regulations.  All of the employees handling chlorine have been thoroughly trained.  This facility has a strong commitment to the safe handling of chlorine and to minimizing the probability of an accidental release.  This is achieved through a combination of personnel training, process safety equipment and operating procedures.

Five-year accident history
The Kemira East Chicago facility has been operational since 2005.  Since that time there have not been any accidental releases of chlorine that led to deaths or injuries of people onsite or offsite or a response or restoration activities at any of the environmental receptors in the last five years.  None of the employees or contractors has been involved in any accidents related to the hazardous substance defined in section 112(r) that is stored or handled at this facility.  Kemira has developed and implemented an extensive program for investigating and follow-up of all accidents/incidents, which may occur in the future at the East Chicago facility.

Emergency Response Program
The facility has a comprehensive emergency response program.  The Emergency Response Plan contains specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of chlorine, procedures to inform the public and health care information.  All employees working with chlorine are given 40-hour Hazardous Waste Operator (HAZWOPER) training with annual 8-hour refreshers.  This plan is coordinated with the Lake County LEPC and was developed in cooperation with the East Chicago Emergency Management Agency.  KemiraA?s personnel are trained to respond to accidental releases of the onsite regulated substance.  In the event of a release at the facility, the Lake County LEPC and East Chicago Fire Department would be notified immediately.  The purpose of the emergency response program at this facility is to comply with the Risk Management and Release Prevention planning requirements as found in 40 CFR Part 68.  The emergency
response plan includes procedures for notification of the local emergency authority as well as the notification of any potentially affected neighbors.
